001// Copyright (c) FIRST and other WPILib contributors.
002// Open Source Software; you can modify and/or share it under the terms of
003// the WPILib BSD license file in the root directory of this project.
004
005package edu.wpi.first.wpilibj;
006
007import static java.util.Objects.requireNonNull;
008
009import edu.wpi.first.hal.NotifierJNI;
010import java.util.concurrent.atomic.AtomicInteger;
011import java.util.concurrent.locks.ReentrantLock;
012
013public class Notifier implements AutoCloseable {
014  // The thread waiting on the HAL alarm.
015  private Thread m_thread;
016  // The lock for the process information.
017  private final ReentrantLock m_processLock = new ReentrantLock();
018  // The C pointer to the notifier object. We don't use it directly, it is
019  // just passed to the JNI bindings.
020  private final AtomicInteger m_notifier = new AtomicInteger();
021  // The time, in seconds, at which the corresponding handler should be
022  // called. Has the same zero as RobotController.getFPGATime().
023  private double m_expirationTimeSeconds;
024  // The handler passed in by the user which should be called at the
025  // appropriate interval.
026  private Runnable m_handler;
027  // Whether we are calling the handler just once or periodically.
028  private boolean m_periodic;
029  // If periodic, the period of the calling; if just once, stores how long it
030  // is until we call the handler.
031  private double m_periodSeconds;
032
033  @Override
034  public void close() {
035    int handle = m_notifier.getAndSet(0);
036    if (handle == 0) {
037      return;
038    }
039    NotifierJNI.stopNotifier(handle);
040    // Join the thread to ensure the handler has exited.
041    if (m_thread.isAlive()) {
042      try {
043        m_thread.interrupt();
044        m_thread.join();
045      } catch (InterruptedException ex) {
046        Thread.currentThread().interrupt();
047      }
048    }
049    NotifierJNI.cleanNotifier(handle);
050    m_thread = null;
051  }
052
053  /**
054   * Update the alarm hardware to reflect the next alarm.
055   *
056   * @param triggerTimeMicroS the time in microseconds at which the next alarm will be triggered
057   */
058  private void updateAlarm(long triggerTimeMicroS) {
059    int notifier = m_notifier.get();
060    if (notifier == 0) {
061      return;
062    }
063    NotifierJNI.updateNotifierAlarm(notifier, triggerTimeMicroS);
064  }
065
066  /** Update the alarm hardware to reflect the next alarm. */
067  private void updateAlarm() {
068    updateAlarm((long) (m_expirationTimeSeconds * 1e6));
069  }
070
071  /**
072   * Create a Notifier for timer event notification.
073   *
074   * @param run The handler that is called at the notification time which is set using StartSingle
075   *     or StartPeriodic.
076   */
077  public Notifier(Runnable run) {
078    requireNonNull(run);
079
080    m_handler = run;
081    m_notifier.set(NotifierJNI.initializeNotifier());
082
083    m_thread =
084        new Thread(
085            () -> {
086              while (!Thread.interrupted()) {
087                int notifier = m_notifier.get();
088                if (notifier == 0) {
089                  break;
090                }
091                long curTime = NotifierJNI.waitForNotifierAlarm(notifier);
092                if (curTime == 0) {
093                  break;
094                }
095
096                Runnable handler;
097                m_processLock.lock();
098                try {
099                  handler = m_handler;
100                  if (m_periodic) {
101                    m_expirationTimeSeconds += m_periodSeconds;
102                    updateAlarm();
103                  } else {
104                    // need to update the alarm to cause it to wait again
105                    updateAlarm((long) -1);
106                  }
107                } finally {
108                  m_processLock.unlock();
109                }
110
111                if (handler != null) {
112                  handler.run();
113                }
114              }
115            });
116    m_thread.setName("Notifier");
117    m_thread.setDaemon(true);
118    m_thread.setUncaughtExceptionHandler(
119        (thread, error) -> {
120          Throwable cause = error.getCause();
121          if (cause != null) {
122            error = cause;
123          }
124          DriverStation.reportError(
125              "Unhandled exception: " + error.toString(), error.getStackTrace());
126          DriverStation.reportError(
127              "The loopFunc() method (or methods called by it) should have handled "
128                  + "the exception above.",
129              false);
130        });
131    m_thread.start();
132  }
133
134  /**
135   * Sets the name of the notifier. Used for debugging purposes only.
136   *
137   * @param name Name
138   */
139  public void setName(String name) {
140    m_thread.setName(name);
141    NotifierJNI.setNotifierName(m_notifier.get(), name);
142  }
143
144  /**
145   * Change the handler function.
146   *
147   * @param handler Handler
148   */
149  public void setHandler(Runnable handler) {
150    m_processLock.lock();
151    try {
152      m_handler = handler;
153    } finally {
154      m_processLock.unlock();
155    }
156  }
157
158  /**
159   * Register for single event notification. A timer event is queued for a single event after the
160   * specified delay.
161   *
162   * @param delaySeconds Seconds to wait before the handler is called.
163   */
164  public void startSingle(double delaySeconds) {
165    m_processLock.lock();
166    try {
167      m_periodic = false;
168      m_periodSeconds = delaySeconds;
169      m_expirationTimeSeconds = RobotController.getFPGATime() * 1e-6 + delaySeconds;
170      updateAlarm();
171    } finally {
172      m_processLock.unlock();
173    }
174  }
175
176  /**
177   * Register for periodic event notification. A timer event is queued for periodic event
178   * notification. Each time the interrupt occurs, the event will be immediately requeued for the
179   * same time interval.
180   *
181   * @param periodSeconds Period in seconds to call the handler starting one period after the call
182   *     to this method.
183   */
184  public void startPeriodic(double periodSeconds) {
185    m_processLock.lock();
186    try {
187      m_periodic = true;
188      m_periodSeconds = periodSeconds;
189      m_expirationTimeSeconds = RobotController.getFPGATime() * 1e-6 + periodSeconds;
190      updateAlarm();
191    } finally {
192      m_processLock.unlock();
193    }
194  }
195
196  /**
197   * Stop timer events from occurring. Stop any repeating timer events from occurring. This will
198   * also remove any single notification events from the queue. If a timer-based call to the
199   * registered handler is in progress, this function will block until the handler call is complete.
200   */
201  public void stop() {
202    m_processLock.lock();
203    try {
204      m_periodic = false;
205      NotifierJNI.cancelNotifierAlarm(m_notifier.get());
206    } finally {
207      m_processLock.unlock();
208    }
209  }
210
211  /**
212   * Sets the HAL notifier thread priority.
213   *
214   * <p>The HAL notifier thread is responsible for managing the FPGA's notifier interrupt and waking
215   * up user's Notifiers when it's their time to run. Giving the HAL notifier thread real-time
216   * priority helps ensure the user's real-time Notifiers, if any, are notified to run in a timely
217   * manner.
218   *
219   * @param realTime Set to true to set a real-time priority, false for standard priority.
220   * @param priority Priority to set the thread to. For real-time, this is 1-99 with 99 being
221   *     highest. For non-real-time, this is forced to 0. See "man 7 sched" for more details.
222   * @return True on success.
223   */
224  public static boolean setHALThreadPriority(boolean realTime, int priority) {
225    return NotifierJNI.setHALThreadPriority(realTime, priority);
226  }
227}
